text: September 2022 was a brutal month, with stocks and bonds down, across sectors and geographies. The ERP for the S&P 500 ended at 6.21%, up from 5.45%, and the https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rate spiked to 3.82% from 3.19%. Risk capital is in full retreat. https://t.co/wy8WGupZeI https://t.co/DOV8dEbDy0
@cetello For a implied forward PE, divide the intrinsic value (3516) by earnings in 2022 (225) = 15.63

You can critique the Fed for not acting sooner or for its actions over the last decade, but at the moment, they are caught between a rock (a recession-induced inflation break) and a hard place (do nothing and let inflation play out). https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP

Your views are likely to be very different from mine and to encompass those differences, here are my estimates of index value for different https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rates, ERP estimates and recession effects on earnings. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/mjLMDXKE6F

I gave it my best shot, knowing that I will be completely wrong in hindsight, and estimated the index value to be 3516, within 5% of its traded price on September 23. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/lU6YBX6UD8

The S&P is down 22.5% in 2022, but to evaluate whether it is time for a contrarian buy or a save-yourself sell, there are key questions about inflation's effects that need to be answered. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/jo1zKmVT9h

The price of risk in equity markets, i.e., the equity risk premium, is also up in 2022. The double whammy of higher https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rates and higher ERP has pushed up the expected return on stocks from 5.75% on 1/1/22 to 9.75% on 9/23. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/Yu1o9Eq6x7

Retreating risk capital pushes up the price of risk in every market. In bond markets, default spreads have widened in 2022, and more so for the lowest rated bonds. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/PFYdmtWQG8

As inflation has risen as a threat, the capital invested in the riskiest assets, i.e., risk capital, has retreated in 2022, as manifested in VC capital investments, IPOs and high yield debt issuances all dropping off in 2022. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/miOGpHdtJv

Rising interest rates in the US are creating chaos in currency markets, as the US dollar approaches all-time highs against the Euro and the Pound, while rising strongly against other currencies as well. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/xOzMm5xf0w

The first order effect of higher expected inflation is in higher interest rates, and you are seeing those higher rates across the US treasury term structure in 2022, with bigger increases in rates at the short end. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/yWW9kA4IX1

The inflation implied in the US treasury market, as the difference between the https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rate and the TIPs rate, is also climbing, albeit at a slower rate, and with a strong term structure (short term inflation > long term inflation). https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/iyGxSEnH58

While the inflation numbers flashed red signals as early as 2021, expectations for future inflation were slow to adjust. In 2022, you are seeing expected inflation climb in surveys, as consumers react to hits to their pocketbooks. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/mCeZQhoTJN

To many investors, consumers and businesses, inflation in 2021 & 2022 has been shocking, because a decade of low and stable inflation lulled them into complacency and left them unprepared. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP https://t.co/aGdjEBfLzC

Inflation has been the big story of 2022, driving markets and pushing central banks and policy makers to react. I update my posts from earlier this year on inflation to reflect what we learned this summer about inflation's persistence & unpredictability. https://t.co/ebNEMbdcFP
@Boris61434332 The term in the brackets (Expected return on market minus riskfree rate) is the equity risk premium. Two ways of stating the same thing.
@_ilchen_ It is not “despite”…. It is “because”… There will be less capital when riskfree rates and risk premiums are high.

I am sorry but I transposed the ERP and https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rate in the chart, for Sept 2021. The corrected figure is below, and you can see that in the last year, the riskfree rate rose (from 1.31% to 3.19%) and the ERP increased (from 4.21% to 5.45%). https://t.co/pSFHuyL1rk

Since inflation concerns first surfaced in early 2021, investors have under estimated its potential for damage and over estimated the Fed's powers to bring it back under control. My picture from May 2022 on how this will play out in the market still holds. https://t.co/s8lVHRkN37 https://t.co/B4fgWcuEFw

To see the details of the ERP calculation, and how the ERP is a composite metric that reflects investor fears & hopes, check out the spreadsheet with the Sept 2022 calculation (https://t.co/ESuHmzGRup) and my website for historical perspective (https://t.co/IfY5XbzQfu).

In the last few days, as cracks emerged in that consensus, with fresh concerns about how soft the landing will be and whether inflation will persist, US stocks are down again, the https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rate is up to 3.19% and the ERP for the S&P 500 rose to 5.45% on 9/1/22. https://t.co/u8Z4x4E55Y

For a market that was unsettled by inflation for much of this year, in July and for much of August, it looked like investors had reached a consensus on a soft landing for the economy & a quick drop off in inflation, allowing US stocks to recover strongly.
@arunkumar_cms Notice the misspelling of my name. That is not me. Sorry!

US stocks showed strength in July, with the S&P 500 rising 9.1% and the https://t.co/jhPnIWvzPT rate dropping to 2.65%. With the ERP dropping from 6.01% to 5.42%, the expected return on stocks is 8.07%. Is the market finding its feet? August will tell us.  https://t.co/IfY5XbiNdu https://t.co/okKJOTOkhM

@BahirwaniKrish @sujitsin Not really. Both your valuation and the market are wrong. The “truth” will take far longer to play out. That is why I did not view my Zomato  valuation as vindication and my Paytm valuation as a mistake. It is still early in the game.

@Valuedontlie @mdbergman36 @DuttonCapital As far as I am concerned, they have always been debt. Accounting has finally come to its senses and is now acknowledging what has always been reality. So, there is less of a gap now between the debt numbers that I use and the accounting debt numbers.

@mdbergman36 @DuttonCapital @Valuedontlie Yes, capitalizing R&D is a good idea and leases are and always have been debt. You don’t even need to break down convertible debt, since both components stay in invested capital, but don’t forget to net out cash.

If you did buy Zomato at its 2021 prices, and feeling regret, please don't attribute to conspiracies (with bankers, founders and analysts as villains) what can be better explained by greed & myopia. You live by momentum, you die by it! https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA

If you are an investor, a week or two more like the last two will make Zomato a buy. If you are a trader, you are better off looking at price charts, consulting an astrologer or visiting your favored place of worship to get a sense of momentum shifts. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/RM3SxyTGFQ

This is my valuation, not the valuation, of Zomato, and needless to say, I will be wrong on every single assumption. Rather than hide from uncertainty, I choose to face up to it. Here are my simulation results for Zomato. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/9qn9XZfQ5g

Updating my valuation to reflect both company and macro news, I adjust my story to reflect a bigger potential market (with grocery deliveries), albeit with lower revenue share and margins and a higher cost of capital to value Zomato at ₹35/share. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/vyGMDBF0b1

In macro changes, inflation has changed and unsettled markets around the world (pushing up risk free rates) and risk capital has gone to the side lines, pushing up equity risk premiums, increasing the costs of capital for all companies. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/TpNFTz8qtm

The company has had four earnings reports, with some good news (sustained growth, a larger cash buffer), some bad (lower take rate, worsening margins) and some questionable (acquisition-driven growth, side investments). https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/09ju37nZjJ

Much as I would like to claim vindication for my value, I attribute the convergence to chance, since (1) I valued Paytm, currently trading at  ₹713 at  ₹2000, (2) You cannot compare a price in July 2022 to a valuation in July 2021. Much has changed! https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA

In 2022, the mood shifted, Zomato rediscovered the laws of gravity, and the stock price dropped. Zomato's acquisition of Blinkit for $568 million ( ₹4500 crores) and the lock-in expiration exacerbated selling, pushing the price down to ₹41. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA

At  the offering, the market had a very different view on the company, as the stock soared 51% from its offering price of ₹74, and Zomato continued to trade at stratospheric levels all through 2021, held up by easy access to risk capital and momentum. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/FlP1v5jMwc

Just over a year ago, I valued Zomato, the Indian food-delivery company, at ₹41/share, ahead of its IPO, and argued that it was joint bet on Indian growth, Indian eating habits and Zomato's business model. In hindsight, I was both wrong and right. https://t.co/DWz0SQyVTA https://t.co/AThITjS2iD

If you find the NYU price tag for the certificate classes too high, I don't control that, but if you are interested in just the content, and will settle for no certification and less polished videos, I have free versions of the classes online. https://t.co/zw2kjb8kpc

To do valuation well, you need to understand how businesses make investment, financing and dividend decisions, i.e., corporate finance, and to make informed corporate finance decisions, it helps to understand how they play out in value.

I love teaching both classes, and while they are both built around the same principles, corporate finance looks at businesses from the inside out (as owners or managers) and valuation looks at the same businesses from the outside in (as investors). https://t.co/VzCxYFAyrR

While these classes are built around recorded lectures and accessible content, there will be live office hours, once every two weeks. Fair warning: There will be exams and a project to do, and it will take a time commitment.

I live the cushy life, teaching my NYU classes only in the spring, and dabbling in anything that interests me for the rest of the year. However, NYU is offering my classes in corporate finance and Valuation, for certification, in the fall. https://t.co/4OBQqb3uJr

@Kirill_Maltsev1 I used the last available rating for Russia, which was Ca, before the ratings agencies withdrew all ratings for the country. It is technically in default, but so are a dozen other countries.

The last six months have been a reminder that the only constant in business & markets is change, and that the biggest enemy to dealing with change that investors and businesses is inertia. It is time to reset perspectives and revisit rules of thumb. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6

Rising interest rates and surging risk premiums in bond and equity markets have conspired to create the biggest increase in costs of capital that I have seen in decades. My estimates for costs of capital in US$ terms for US & Global companies in July 2022. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/7xD2e8nEpC

It has been an eventful six months for all markets, as equity risk premiums have risen about 2-3%, driven by inflation worries and economic concerns, but these ten countries saw the biggest increases (and there are no surprises) in ERPs. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/Grws4BQ5Sg

If you don't trust ratings agencies, or believe that they are biased, the sovereign CDS market offers a market-based estimate of default spreads for countries, albeit only for about half of all countries. Here are the July 2022 numbers. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/K02b1HNmMe

Sovereign default risk is a narrower measure of country risk, but it is often the most widely used and is tailored for finance. Ratings agencies capture exposure with sovereign ratings, and here are Moody's sovereign ratings for countries in July 2022. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/srqDzVuX0C

There are services that measure composite risk in countries, albeit with idiosyncrasies that make the score difficult to convert to financial metrics. The PRS Group, one of my favorites, estimates risk scores (higher is safer) at the start of July 2022. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/cvwD00Jd6H

The value of the business rests on the protections for property rights, and risk increases in countries where there are no legal protections or the legal system does not offer timely recourse. A picture of property rights around the world from IPRI. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/irWsmTbO4L

Corruption operates as a hidden tax, increasing the cost of doing business and/or handicapping more scrupulous businesses. The most recent update on how the extent of corruption varies across the world, from Transparency Intel. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/Fs3Q5821bj

Operating a business becomes riskier and more difficult in countries that are more exposed to violence, from war, terrorism or internal strife, than in more peaceful ones. A picture of how exposure to violence varies across countries in 2022, from the IPF. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/gjZbi1ZgBJ

The link between business risk and political freedom/democracy is a complex one, with more continuous risk in democracies (as elections create changes) and more discontinuous risk in authoritarian regimes from regime changes. I prefer the former! https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/f87q0suzKa

Risk varies across countries for many reasons, including country size and over-dependence on a sector or commodity, as well as maturity of the economy, but political structure, legal protections, exposure to violence and extent of corruption play a role. https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6 https://t.co/zQAUfYwqr2

As we all look outside domestic markets for returns, understanding why risk varies across countries and how to measure it becomes a key. My 2022 mid-year update for country risk is up. Paper: https://t.co/IsDUFjrdwc Post: https://t.co/q4BvkjK7M6, Data: https://t.co/2GDvL7mjAL https://t.co/O5bU7lJkLU

@JGT2799 @IlariLehti @choffstein If investors can invest only locally, you will end up with partially diversified investors and companies will then face higher costs of equity than they would in a world where investors are diversified. A beta estimated against a local index will yield too low a cost of equity.

@IlariLehti @JGT2799 @choffstein Good points, but going back to your starting point, none of this ensues if the investors in Techopolis and Energyland are able to diversify outside their countries. If they are, the fact that the countries are sector-dominated will not matter, and thank God for that!

@Unclerobbie1 @JRogrow It may be because I chose to capitalize leases on my own (I don’t remember now) and used my lease debt to substitute for the accounting estimates. It reflects my deep rooted distrust of accountants, but you should be okay using accounting lease debt.
@Unclerobbie1 @JRogrow Should be on the balance sheet, labeled as such. Are you working with the right quarter’s balance sheet? That may be the source of the problem.

@JRogrow @Unclerobbie1 Just to clarify. It is all interest bearing debt, which includes short term and short term portion of long term debt under current liabilities, long term debt and lease debt (shown on balance sheet since 2019).

This may sound callous, but a longer term pullback might be healthy for both investors and businesses, since a decade of easy access to risk capital has made us all sloppy and lazy. The pain, though, will be real, and old lessons will have to be relearned. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD

The big question for investors and businesses is whether the risk capital pullback is temporary like 2020 or longer term, as it was in 2001 and 2009. My guess is that it is the latter, since inflation has neutered central banks & governments. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD

As risk capital has withdrawn from the market, stocks are down, but they are down more for the riskiest segments of public markets (negative earnings and high growth companies), and in private markets, with more down rounds & failures for young companies. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD https://t.co/IBFlkAwkzC

The risk capital pull back in 2022 has had a drastic effect on expected returns on stocks, with the equity risk premium for the S&P 500 rising from 4.24% to 6.43% and the 10-yr T Bond rate from 1.51% to 3.02%, between 1/1/22 and 6/30/22. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD https://t.co/iJGlK2HPE6

Looking at the risk capital proxies over the last 30 months (2020 - Mid 2022), you can see that risk capital was resilient through 2020's COVID tests, but all three are showing signs of pull back in 2022. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD https://t.co/P6a3wCldtm

For historical perspective, I use three proxies for the availability and access to risk capital, fund flows to VC, the number/proceeds from IPOs and high-yield corporate bond issuances. They move together, with long prolonged dips after 2000 and 2008. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD https://t.co/dAxLdAXUsm

A healthy market needs balance, with too much (little) risk capital resulting in risk premiums becoming too low (high), price running ahead of (trailing) value and too much (little) capital invested in young, risky businesses. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD https://t.co/Wxvt2eDsQY

The amount of risk capital will vary across investors, and for every investor, across time, driven by risk aversion, market momentum & the health/stability of the economy, with low interest rates and low/stable inflation providing a boost to risk taking https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD

Risk capital is the portion of capital invested in the riskiest segments of markets (stocks, bonds, real estate, collectibles) and its foil is safety capital, invested in the safest segments, with greed driving the former & fear the latter. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD https://t.co/HFci5O5BAt

It has been a brutal first half of 2022 for markets, across geographies and asset classes. While this may be a correction that is long overdue, I address the question of why now and how much (correction) is too much, using risk capital as my lens. https://t.co/KPeAGHPKHD
@Shrikanth_M_SK Actually, I do have one h in my name, not two.

@Shrikanth_M_SK There has never been an h in my name, but I do have books on valuation and I have been around a while. So, you probably used my book in your class. Hope it did not create too much damage.

@brentsheather On the contrary, when investing in stocks, a long-term default-free rate is the only relevant risk free rate. A 6-month T.Bill rate is not risk free, since you will have roll the investment over multiple times to get a time horizon that matters, and at rates you do not know today

After a rough three weeks to start the month, the S&P 500 recouped its losses, to end May 2022 roughly where it started. The equity risk premium dropped from 5.14% to 5.07%, as analysts scaled back earnings mildly, but inflation remains the wild card. https://t.co/IfY5XbzQfu https://t.co/6GPg6VZWNx
@BrainportI Expected devaluation is in your cash flows and it comes from differential inflation. Unexpected devaluation is in your country risk premium.

@BrainportI There is no inflation risk. There is uncertainty about inflation risk, and that may push up your ERP, and this has nothing to do with domestic or foreign investors. Everyone feels it and prices it in.

@spaultweet To be honest, it remains a mystery to me, since you can argue that at least, on average, many of the factors work against small companies. But there is a healthy segment of small caps that are low risk, have stable earnings and very little debt, and they may be the source.

If you are a value investor, you may feel vindication, viewing 2022 as a return to good sense, but withhold celebrating. Whether the trend so far in 2022 continues for the rest of the year will depend on how inflation unfolds for the rest of the year. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz

Even within sectors like technology, the differences in returns across companies can be traced to cash flows and risk, with older, more positive cash flow generating companies outperforming younger, money losing companies. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/ROGSAnQUcx

The best performing sectors in the US, so far in 2022, are energy (by a wide margin) and utilities. The worst are technology, consumer discretionary & communications. Other than energy, every other sector is in the red. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/wIWXNjkE4E

Adding on, low risk companies have outperformed the market in 2022, as have companies with more positive cash flows from operations and more cash returned to shareholders (in dividends). https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/2AYjZCTfE0

In 2022, when inflationreturned to dominate the conversation, the small cap and value effects have returned, albeit over a small sample period. Small caps outperformed large caps and low price to book stocks beat the market. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/6z7sPIFUTO

Looking across the decades at the small cap premium and the value factor show that small cap stocks perform best in decades when inflation is higher than expected, and that the value effect also benefits from inflation. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/ZGIt7GHfFL

Put simply a company with pricing power, low input costs & short term/flexible investments is better positioned to weather inflation than one without these characteristics. Having stable earnings and low debt help as well. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/ymwIE3v7nd

To make this assessment, I look at how inflation affects each of the drivers of value, and how the net effect that it has on cash flows and risk determine how much or how little a company is hurt by higher than expected inflation. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz https://t.co/uFG4grsytp

As a follow up to my last post on inflation, where I pointed to its effect on asset classes (bad for financial assets, better for real assets), I look at its disparate effects across companies, and why some are more exposed to inflation than others. https://t.co/YjLZxjqOEz

@markjmessmer In keeping with the old rule when it comes to holes, if you are in one, stop digging. The $1.9 trillion COVID package passed in 2021 was an abomination, with the money spent vastly disproportionate to the help it priovided. If there is original sin in this sequence, that’s it.

The inflation genie is out of the bottle, and getting it back in will take more time and more pain than we realize. Failure to act quickly and decisively in early 2021 has put us between a rock (high inflation) and a hard place (a recession). https://t.co/IctOQRYzih

There is significant divergence of views on every aspect of value, from where https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rates will end up, to whether risk premiums will continue to rise, to how a slowdown may damage earnings, leading to a wide range of values for the index. https://t.co/IctOQRYzih https://t.co/dY1qFWZGcx

Higher and more volatile inflation is playing out in every aspect of stock prices, and the consensus view, with https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rates at 3%, ERP at 5.24% and earnings staying resilient translates into a value very close to current index levels. https://t.co/IctOQRYzih https://t.co/W4zxSkTbGc

As inflation gets entrenched, it is having real world consequences on interest rates, as yields rise and the yield curve flattens out, on risk premiums, as default spreads & equity risk premiums increase, and in more worries about an economic slowdown. https://t.co/IctOQRYzih https://t.co/QyQLfUpQ1G

Initially, the reappearance of inflation was explained away as temporary, with COVID, supply chains & Russia all blamed, but the realization that inflation is not transient and is not going away is finally gaining acceptance. https://t.co/IctOQRYzih https://t.co/Qyi0aWXZSl

Stock and bond markets are unsettled, because of the threat of inflation. We were spoilt by a decade of low and stable inflation, and there are many in this market who have never dealt with high and unpredictable inflation. https://t.co/IctOQRYzih https://t.co/dZQROqS49u

@berthon_jones @Vera_Icona_23 There are two short cuts to get expected return. One is to just use the EP ratio and assume that reinvestment is value neutral. The other is to take the dividend or cash yield and add the long term growth in earnings to get expected return. This approach mixes the two.

@Vera_Icona_23 Your starting statement is nonsense, since this ERP is built on the assumption of 7.69%  growth in earnings for the next 5 years, and 2.89% after. Adding a growth rate to an EP ratio to get an ERP is valuation malpractice, and your graph just visualizes that malpractice.

I believe that earnings for the S&P 500 still don't reflect the hit from a possible recession, and as that unfolds, there will be more price adjustment ahead. We are paying the price for not taking inflation seriously and early enough. https://t.co/l3t1h1Q6v0

On Jan 1, 2022, the https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rate of 1.51% added to ERP of 4.24%, yielded an expected return on stocks of 5.75%. On May 1, 2022, a mix of higher https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rates (2.89%) and ERP (5.14%) pushed expected return to 8.03%. The period statistics are below: https://t.co/nsV002sqnc

April 2022 was a brutal month for stocks and T.Bonds, as the https://t.co/jhPnIWMCRT rate rose from 2.33% to 2.89% and the S&P 500 dropped by 8.8%. The ERP rose to 5.14% (from  4.73%) and the expected annual return on stocks is now 8.03%. ERP spreadsheet: https://t.co/l3t1h1Q6v0 https://t.co/ltiTps4XvQ
I had fun chatting with @williamgreen72 on his podcast about everything from ESG to Bitcoin to Tesla. You can listen at https://t.co/9qxWBetOHS or watch at  https://t.co/MaVpgJxDRZ.

The edit button on Twitter cannot get here soon enough. In my thread on Elon's Twitter bid, I linked to my 2013 Twitter IPO post, by mistake. If you are interested, this is the link to the new post. https://t.co/pllAm9vYrK. My YouTube video https://t.co/yT2IDGXFBQ via @YouTube
@RomanSPQR They are both linked in the post.

Put simply, we are drawn to Twitter for the same reasons that we slow down on highways to look at car crashes, or gather around schoolyards to watch fights. I am still wrestling with whether it is a net good or a net bad for society.  https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97

To those who are elevating Twitter to some type of national treasure, that should be preserved in its current form, just stop! It is a platform for breaking news, but it is the deranged arguments between out-of-control people that are its biggest draw. https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97

This is more a political than a financial story, since where you fall on the political divide largely determine whether you think the Elon acquisition deal should go through or not. There is plenty of hypocrisy and wishful thinking on both sides. https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97

There are four possible endings to the story, from least to most likely: (1) Status quo  (2) Musk takes Twitter private, (3) Twitter is taken private by someone else & (4) Twitter stays a public company, with someone else running it. https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97

Musk's challenge is that markets don't believe that he will follow through, and it is not clear what changes he has mind for Twitter's business model, since almost all of his focus has been on the free speech component. https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97

It is possible that the company's value could be higher than Musk's offer price, if run differently, but how can incumbent management make that argument credibly, given that they have been running the company for a decade? https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97

Twitter's management argument that Musk's offer lowballs the company's value does not hold up to scrutiny, if the company is valued with existing management in place. https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97 https://t.co/y0hGn03VqN

Elon Musk's announcement that he had acquired a 9.2% stake in Twitter on April 4 has triggered a dizzying sequence of events at the company. I try my best to disentangle the valuation, corporate governance and political questions in the deal. https://t.co/hKPfmXsm97 https://t.co/UZUdPlX670

I have an obsession with equity risk premiums, and I write an annual update on estimating and using these premiums, in exhaustive & boring detail. This year’s update is a month late, but is available at https://t.co/0lVwfwOuM1. Hope you find it useful or at least sleep inducing.

In my teaching, I have the luxury of time, and I am verbose. TEDx, with its tight time constraints, is not my preferred habitat, but I will be on tomorrow on TEDxGateway, talking about the corporate life cycle. If you can make it, I'll see you there: https://t.co/Pj82EkbQ6G

Russia was the lead story last month, but inflation remains more consequential, long term. Stocks were down, the https://t.co/jhPnIWv20l rate jumped, the ERP barely budged (4.73% vs 4.75%), but stocks were priced to earn >7% for 1st time since Jan 2020. https://t.co/wy8WGu8ona https://t.co/buA6LwgVzO

@esgarchitect Fair enough. I think you are taking my disagreement with ESG as a concept with disagreement about wanting to make the world a better place. We all want the latter. I just don’t see a pathway where ESG gets us there. In fact, I see lots of pathways where it makes it worse.

There is no light at the end of the ESG tunnel. If you work in the space, your choices are to be a useful idiot, toiling in the trenches, for what you think is a good cause, be a feckless knave, in it just for the money, or find something else to do.  https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb

ESG utopians believe that the problem with ESG is that it is mis-measured and misused. However, ESG mis-measurement is endemic, greenwashing is an ESG feature, not an ESG bug, and underperformance is what you should expect in steady state, for ESG funds. https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb

ESG expansionists argue that the solution is to bring in Russia-like risks into ESG scores, but expanding ESG to include missed risks, after every crisis, and political risks, specifically, will make a bloated measure even more so. https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb

Just as a thought experiment, if China invaded Taiwan, do you think firms would be abandoning Chinese operations, fund managers selling Chinese holdings, and individuals giving up all things Chinese as easily as they gave up Russian vodka? I don't! https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb

Some ESG advocates point to the corporate & investor pull out from Russia, after Ukraine, as evidence of better behavior, but it is easy to be moral when you are giving up a tiny slice of revenues and those operations are no longer economically viable. https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb

Leading into the Russia crisis, ESG services were missing Russia in their ESG scores, ESG-driven companies persisted with Russia investments and ESG funds continued to have money at risk, that they lost, in Russia. (Graph from a paper by Baruch Lev et al.) https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb https://t.co/ppb1N6vVdp

When I first wrote about ESG in Sept 2020, I thought it was a flawed concept that could be fixed with better implementation and execution. The more I have learn about ESG, the less merit I see in it, and I use the Russia crisis to pick at its carcass. https://t.co/HpqxcohLLb

@bmwravi @GrowthyValue @williamgreen72 You never discount at the treasury rate. @DavidKleinbard @dab_sat @GeorgeThampy The selling point for gold is not that it is a good investment, standing alone. It is not, ane never will be. It is that it can be a good add on to a portfolio of financial assets, because it provides insurance against crises and inflation. That is the role of a collectible.

@dab_sat @DavidKleinbard @GeorgeThampy Good collectibles have enduring value, aesthetic attraction, and hold value during crisis. Gold is a good collectible, as are diamonds and fine art. Investors who insist on making double digit returns on stocks, and companies that have concocted hurdle rates of 12% or 15%, in US % terms, have to choose between being shut out of markets or adjusting expectations.  https://t.co/GCtGsg24iz

A combination of low risk free rates and low risk premiums in equity and bond markets has pushed the costs of capital for companies down towards historic lows, to begin 2022. The median $ cost of capital for a global (US) company is 6.33% (5.77%). https://t.co/GCtGsg24iz https://t.co/198fdoba9z

Debt can be a source of capital, and while it is cheaper than equity, and provides tax benefits, increasing debt in your capital mix does not always translate into lower hurdle rates. https://t.co/GCtGsgj7kz https://t.co/Kl4o5dsgfN

To go from abstract risk measures to hurdle rates, I find it easiest to keep things simple: the currency determines your risk free rate, your business mix your relative risk and your operating geographies your equity risk premium. https://t.co/GCtGsg24iz https://t.co/cKUYH8lV9Y

When valuing companies, you face multiple uncertainties, but categorizing them into estimation vs economic, micro vs macro and continuous vs discrete helps you understand and deal with risk better. https://t.co/GCtGsgj7kz https://t.co/LkShQvbEkn

The best definition of risk is the Chinese symbol for crisis, which is a combination of symbols for danger and opportunity. In investing, opportunity without danger in investing is a mirage (or scam), and danger without opportunity is foolhardy. https://t.co/GCtGsgj7kz https://t.co/bTdMPQzYhf

The inflation surge seems to be global, but expected inflation, coming in 2022, varies across countries and currencies. Inflation expectations affect currency interest rates, with high (low) inflation currencies exhibiting the highest (lowest) rates. https://t.co/JAqUpBW5TN https://t.co/qDfyAb627c

Historically, real estate has been a neutral hedge, with returns rising to match inflation, but gold has been an inflation bet, delivering its highest returns when inflation is much higher than expected and abysmal returns when it is much lower. https://t.co/JAqUpBW5TN https://t.co/PuYAu25VGy

If you break equities down into sub-groups, unexpected inflation has had disparate effects, with small cap companies and stocks trading at low pricing multiples benefiting (hurting) when inflation is higher (lower) than expected. https://t.co/JAqUpBW5TN https://t.co/NxUdtFIbDP

If you break inflation in any period into expected and unexpected inflation, it is the latter that blindsides investors and businesses. For stocks and fixed income, unexpectedly high inflation has never been good news. https://t.co/JAqUpBW5TN https://t.co/MdIAxRTAAo

The effects of higher-than-expected inflation on nominal & real returns on stocks and bonds can be seen in historical returns over time. Take a look at annual returns in the 1970s (highest inflation) and 2010-19 (lowest inflation): https://t.co/s3Wn6PzyK6 https://t.co/m64XfhSoPL

Higher-than-expected inflation inflicts direct damage on bonds, as rates rise. Their effect of stocks is more complex, with discount rates and cash flows rising, but the net effect, at least in the aggregate, is more likely to be negative than positive. https://t.co/s3Wn6PzyK6 https://t.co/r7czZCgm1M

Inflation is currency specific, & differences explain why interest rates vary across currencies and exchange rates. Here are expected inflation rates for 2021-26, by country, from the IMF. Expectations that inflation will rise are becoming more broad based, as can be seen in both a bond market based measure (https://t.co/jhPnIWv20l - TIPs) and consumer surveys. https://t.co/s3Wn6PzyK6 https://t.co/Qn3I1V5Dk1

While US stocks have done well, so far, in 2021, the market is caught between two forces, a stronger than expected economy as a positive and worries about inflation as a negative. Comparing the power of different measures of ERP to predict stock market returns over next decade, the current implied ERP does best (albeit with noise) and that historical ERPs do worst.  (Look at correlations with actual 10-yr ERPs)  https://t.co/yALxcDRxex https://t.co/8z32vRGF7v

The price of risk (ERP) in equity markets moves mostly in sync with the price of risk in bond markets (default spreads) and when it does not (late 1990s, 2002-08), chaos ensues. Real estate is behaving more like stocks now than a divergent asset class. https://t.co/yALxcDRxex https://t.co/CRZigCSPSk

An implied ERP, computed from current stock prices and expected future cash flows, is a more forward-looking and dynamic estimate. At the start of 2021, this ERP was 4.72% after a tumultuous ride during 2020. https://t.co/yALxcDRxex https://t.co/J8qGOMVITd

In practice, most analysts and companies estimate equity risk premiums by looking at the past (historical data), but that is not only backward looking, but it yields static and noisy estimates of the ERP, even for a market like the US, with a long history. https://t.co/yALxcDRxex https://t.co/dIzTakOrdg

As the ERP rises and falls, it drives what investors are willing to pay for stocks, and what companies demand as hurdle rates. Views on whether it is too high or too low determine whether stocks are collectively under or over valued. https://t.co/yALxcDRxex https://t.co/yiMZhZ0XBj

The equity risk premium (ERP) is the price of risk in equity markets, the receptacle for all our fears. Each year, since 2008, I have updated a paper that includes everything I know about ERP. @MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread You are right. If you have a traded bond, you can back out the probability of failure from the price. I have a spreadsheet that does that on my website.

@MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread The bond yield is based upon the presumption that the promised bond payments will be made (just check the YTM calculations). It is therefore a cost of capital for a going concern that makes it debt payments.
@MarkRozeboom I like Shiller, but I think the Shiller PE was a bludgeon for market assesssment, and not amount of tinkering with it can fix its fundamental flaws.

@MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread First, when was the last time any one valued a company with probability-weighted cash flows? Second, even if you did, the discount rate is designed to reflect the likelihood that you will be wrong on your year 3 cash flows, not that there will be no year 3.

@MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread To get the failure probability, you can use the failure probabilities in bond ratings, the likelihood of failure in a simulation or base it on historical failure rates for firms in that grouping.

@MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread Discount rates are blunt instruments that capture continuous risk in operations. Failure risk is discrete & often catastrophic. You cannot bring that into a DCF. It has to be a post DCF adjustment, consequential for young & distressed companies, and for all firms, during crises.

@EigenegiE Net margins are very volatile, especially in sectors with high fixed costs and leverage. Operating margins are less so and gross margins are more stable. That is what I meant about climbing the income statement.

@EigenegiE Sales are less volatile, but you cannot pay out sales. You first have to earn profits (and margins are volatile) and then pay cash out of these earnings. You cannot make uncertainty go away by climbing the income statement.

@WSBtronResearch @NosaMUgiagbe @ParikPatelCFA I prefer to think of it as dynamic, not falling on a spectrum, which means that it will be different tomorrow and next week. So, I am all for revisiting and reestimating ERP on a continuous basis, not view it as a number that is fixed for the long term.

@ParikPatelCFA Here is the problem with that theory. The ERP today is higher than it was 2 years ago and definitely much higher than its historic norm (4.20% average from 1960-2020). It is the riskfree rate that has dropped, and the debate is really about whether it will stay low.

There are two effects of a crisis. One is lower expected earnings/CF in the future & the other is a higher price for risk. If I ignore the first, my ERP has to be much higher since all of the price drop has to show up in it. Bringing in the CF effect reduces that impact.

I do believe that charts and indicators (especially volume) can be useful in timing trades on individual stocks and detecting shifts in momentum on these stocks. But market indicators, not so much!

@mark_ungewitter @ek1uno True, but be more skeptical of market timing indicators. There have been only 9 bull markets since 1926, and statistically, it is impossible to separate luck from something that works with 9 observations. You can make market timing assertions, but you can't call them laws.

@mark_ungewitter @ek1uno That is exactly why it is a buzzword. When the backing for it is a made-up rule, not data or evidence or even common sense, you have a problem. Every bull market in history, including this last one, is carried forward by the top 10% of stocks, not the middle 50%.
@ek1uno Market breadth is not a story. It’s a buzzword.

@florin__bora The model does not forecast an annual return for next year, just a compounded average return over the long term. Actual returns will always over or under shoot. That is why stocks are risky.
@bratwww Yardeni’s estimates are on the low end this year, but his historical forecasts have been good. The consensus estimate is closer to the 6.5% growth, on a compounded basis over next 5 years.

@rossco_949 @Zizouology24x7 If you go the S&P website, you can download the trailing 12 month numbers. You can then convert into index units by multiplying by (S&P 500 Index Level/ Market Cap of S&P 500). The latter is also available on the site.

@bratwww The bottom up estimates, which is what you find on most sites, is from analyst estimates of company-specific growth and will always be biased upwards. You need forecasts of forward earnings, preferably top down. I use Yardeni’s forecasts. See the excel spreadsheet for details

Data on Buybacks #5: Notion that investing back in businesses is better than returning cash is certainly not true for investors, but it is also not true for economies. Data on Buybacks #4c: Companies that expect lower growth in revenues in future years buy back more of their stock than high growth companies, though there are some outliers in the latter. https://t.co/vCW46nhyPu https://t.co/d1RSIRxx8h
Buyback Data #4b: Big US companies buy back more of their stock, in both absolute and relative terms than small US companies. https://t.co/vCW46nhyPu https://t.co/bUw11eX3Xy

Data on Buybacks  #4a: US Companies in industries that have a history of large dividend payments tend to buy back the least stock. Tech and drug companies are the biggest buyers of their own stock. https://t.co/vCW46nhyPu https://t.co/r9GPC9fIG5

Data on Buybacks #3: Netting out stock issuances against buybacks to get a net cash return and treating R&D as a capital expenditure changes the reinvestment picture. Net cash returned at US companies in 2018 was 45.97% of Net Income+ R&D. https://t.co/vCW46nhyPu https://t.co/5g3E3q2GcV

Data on Buybacks #2: Looking at total cash return (dividends + buybacks) as a percent of accounting net income at US companies, it looks like they reinvesting less and less. In 2018, dividends + buybacks were 92.12% of net income. (But read data #3) https://t.co/vCW46nhyPu https://t.co/lG0iOM1eke

Data on Buybacks #1: Buybacks are big, and getting bigger, for US companies, both in dollar terms and as percentage of cash returned. In 2018, they represented more than 60% of cash returned by S&P 500 companies. https://t.co/vCW46nhyPu https://t.co/xhMHcEWQWm

@DantonQu Nope. My equity risk premium does not come from a model. It is backed out of current stoc prices and has no link to betas, the CAPM or any other straw men you want to fight.

@DantonQu Risk premiums don’t come from what companies make as ROIC. They come from how the stock is priced & what return you make on your investment. So, there is a positive risk premium & companies are making bad investments.

@Michael46830937 My implied cost of equity for the market is model agnostic. It is an IRR based on stock prices & expected cash flows. It was 8.7% for US stocks. No need for CAPM or behavioral finance.

@Michael46830937 Close. Cost of capital is an opportunity cost, given the risk of your company. The cost of funding is what it costs you to raise capital. For companies with easy access to capital markets, the two will converge.
